questions.text: Read the following passage carefully and answer the questions given below:
questions.passage: Discipline must be enforced early in life. Discipline at home makes for the future greatness of a boy. It forms his character and makes him a fit citizen. The child who is allowed to have his own way becomes way-ward. The child who is allowed all sorts of excesses like running about in the sun, exposing himself to cold, eating wholesome things, as a result will fall ill frequently. A child, whose habits have been disciplined and who has been taught to rise early, attend to his lessons properly, take physical exercises at the proper time and avoid things that are injurious will grow up to be a useful member of the society. The spoilt child who has been allowed to run his own course will show vice in younger days. His parents would wish that he had not been born at all.

parts.statement: What does discipline do for a child?

options.text: forms character and makes him a fit citizen.

parts.correct_answer: forms character and makes him a fit citizen.
parts.explanation: The passage states, 'It forms his character and makes him a fit citizen.'

parts.statement: What is the result of allowed all sorts of excesses to a child?

options.text: He will be a useful member of the society.
He will be a fit citizen.

parts.explanation: The passage mentions that a child allowed excesses 'will fall ill frequently.'

parts.statement: What does 'way-ward' mean?
parts.explanation: 'Way-ward' means difficult to control or predict because of unusual behaviour (Synonym: unmanageable).

parts.statement: What does a spoilt child show in younger days?
parts.explanation: The passage states, 'The spoilt child who has been allowed to run his own course will show vice in younger days.'

parts.statement: The opposite of 'injurious' is:
parts.explanation: 'Injurious' means harmful; 'advantageous' means beneficial or helpful, which is its opposite.

questions.text: Read the following passage carefully and answer the questions given below:
questions.passage: Lal Bahadur Shastri was the second Prime Minister of India. He was born on October 2, 1904, at Mughalsarai, a small railway town, seven miles from Varanasi in Uttar Pradesh. His father was a school teacher. He died when Lal Bahadur was only a year and a half old. His mother, Ramdulari Devi, took him and his two sisters to her father’s house. Lal Bahadur's childhood was spent at his grandfather’s house. As a boy, he was quiet, serious, and thought-ful. He was a great patriot. His greatest moment came in 1965 when Pakistan attacked India. As Prime Minister, Lal Bahadur Shastri led the nation to victory. He died at Tashkent on January 11, 1966. He was the first person to be posthumously awarded the Bharat Ratna. His term of Prime Ministership may have been short but his contribution to the nation was tremendous. He gave the slogan 'Jai Jawan, Jai Kisan'.

parts.statement: Who was Lal Bahadur Shastri?

options.text: The first Prime Minister of India
The third Prime Minister of India
The second Prime Minister of India
The fourth Prime Minister of India

parts.correct_answer: The second Prime Minister of India
parts.explanation: The passage states, 'Lal Bahadur Shastri was the second Prime Minister of India.'

parts.statement: When was Lal Bahadur Shastri born?
parts.explanation: The passage mentions his birthdate: 'He was born on October 2, 1904.'

parts.statement: Lal Bahadur Shastri’s father was a:
parts.explanation: The passage states, 'His father was a school teacher.'

parts.statement: Lal Bahadur Shastri’s greatest moment was in 1965 when:

options.text: he gave the slogan 'Jai Jawan, Jai Kisan'.
he was posthumously awarded the Bharat Ratna.

parts.explanation: The passage notes, 'His greatest moment came in 1965 when Pakistan attacked India. As Prime Minister, Lal Bahadur Shastri led the nation to victory.'

parts.statement: Which of the following is the correct slogan given by Lal Bahadur Shastri?
parts.explanation: The passage concludes, 'He gave the slogan 'Jai Jawan, Jai Kisan'.'

questions.text: Read the following passage carefully and answer the questions given below:
questions.passage: In a village lived a poor old woman. She had a cow which grazed on the village common land and yielded enough milk for her. Once the cow grew ill. The old woman could not afford to get a doctor. She ran to her neighbour, a witch, and asked her for help. The witch said, “I will help you on one condition. You must let me suck your cow's milk for three months. Also, if you do not pay me in time, I will curse your cow.” The old woman was very sad. But she had no other choice. So she agreed. The witch gave the woman a medicine for her cow. The cow recovered. The woman was overjoyed. In her joy, she forgot the condition of the witch. She did not give any milk to the witch for three months. The witch became angry and put a curse on the cow. The cow fell sick again. The old woman took the help of the witch again. She gave a curse-removal medicine to the cow. When the old woman returned home, she saw the cow grazing on the common land. The old woman was a little wiser this time. She decided to keep her promise to the witch.

essay_topics.name: On the basis of your reading of the above passage, make notes on it.
essay_topics.answer:
1. The Poor Old Woman (W) and her Cow
    1.1 W lived in a village.
    1.2 Cow grazed on common land; provided milk.
    1.3 Cow fell ill; W could not afford a doctor.
2. Help from the Witch (WH)
    2.1 WH agreed to help on conditions:
        2.1.1 W must give WH cow's milk for 3 months.
        2.1.2 Failure to pay would result in a curse.
    2.2 WH gave medicine; cow recovered.
3. The Broken Promise and Second Sickness
    3.1 W forgot the condition due to joy.
    3.2 W did not pay the milk for 3 months.
    3.3 WH became angry and cursed the cow.
    3.4 Cow fell sick again.
4. Second Recovery and Resolution
    4.1 W took WH's help again (received curse-removal medicine).
    4.2 W became wiser (learned a lesson).
    4.3 W decided to keep her promise to WH.

essay_topics.name: Give a suitable title to it.
essay_topics.answer: The Witch and the Old Woman's Cow / The Lesson of the Broken Promise / Honesty Pays

questions.text: You are Naveen/Neha of Class X in Govt. H.S. School, Bhopal. Write an application to your Principal/Headmaster for granting you Full Fee Concession.

parts.statement: Application to Principal for Full Fee Concession.
parts.explanation:
Reference: Formal application to the Principal.
Context: Student from an economically weak background requests full fee waiver.
Explanation: The application must be formal and polite, addressing the Principal, stating the subject (Full Fee Concession). The body should clearly mention the student's name, class, and the reason (father's low income/inability to afford fees) and request the concession. It should end with an expression of gratitude and the student's promise to work hard.

parts.statement: Write a letter to your friend inviting him to attend the birthday party of your younger brother/sister.
parts.explanation:
Reference: Informal letter to a friend.
Context: The writer invites a friend to a sibling's birthday celebration.
Explanation: The letter should be warm and personal, mentioning the date, time, and venue of the party. It should convey the fun and excitement expected and strongly urge the friend to attend, concluding with regards.

questions.text: Write an essay in about 150 words on any one of the following topics:

parts.statement: An Indian Festival (e.g., Diwali)
parts.explanation:
Context: Describes the cultural and religious importance of a festival.
Explanation: The essay should detail the significance (victory of light over darkness, return of Rama, worship of Lakshmi), the celebration (cleaning, decoration, lighting diyas, fireworks), and the community spirit of the festival.

parts.statement: Science in Our Daily Life
parts.explanation:
Context: Explores the ubiquitous role of science in modern existence.
Explanation: The essay must highlight key scientific contributions—like electricity, transportation, communication devices (mobile phones), and modern medicine—demonstrating how they have made life safer, faster, and more comfortable.

parts.statement: My Hobby
parts.explanation:
Context: Describes a personal leisure activity.
Explanation: The student should select a hobby, explaining its personal value (e.g., stress relief, skill development, knowledge gain) and how they pursue it in their spare time.

parts.statement: The Value of Games and Sports
parts.explanation:
Context: Highlights the benefits of physical activities.
Explanation: The essay should focus on benefits like physical health, mental sharpness, and the development of essential life skills such as teamwork, discipline, leadership, and resilience.

questions.text: On the basis of the picture given below, write a short paragraph about the advantages of trees.

image_data.description: The visual input shows a depiction of trees and highlights their multiple advantages for the environment and human life, such as providing oxygen, rain, shade, food, and purifying the air.

parts.statement: I {BLANK} a letter to my friend yesterday.
parts.explanation: The time expression 'yesterday' requires the Simple Past tense (wrote).

parts.statement: The cat jumped {BLANK} the table.
parts.explanation: 'Onto' correctly expresses movement towards a surface (the table) where the cat will land.

parts.statement: He is {BLANK} M.L.A.
parts.explanation: 'M.L.A.' starts with a vowel sound (em-el-ay), so 'an' is used.

parts.statement: I have been living here {BLANK} four years.
parts.explanation: 'For' is used to denote a duration or period of time ('four years').

parts.statement: We {BLANK} follow the rules of the road.
parts.explanation: 'Must' expresses strong obligation or necessity (it is mandatory to follow traffic rules).

parts.statement: There is not {BLANK} water in the pool.
parts.explanation: 'Much' is used with uncountable nouns ('water') in negative sentences.

parts.statement: The man {BLANK} the police arrested last night is a thief.
parts.explanation: 'Whom' is the objective case relative pronoun used to refer to a person when they are the object of the verb in the clause ('the police arrested whom').

parts.statement: He does his work. (Change into negative)
parts.explanation: He does not do his work.

parts.statement: The man is so weak that he cannot stand. (Rewrite the sentence using 'too...to')
parts.explanation: The man is too weak to stand.

parts.statement: He is my brother. He is wearing a red shirt. (Combine the sentences using a relative clause)
parts.explanation: He is my brother who is wearing a red shirt.

parts.statement: They are selling their house. (Change into present perfect tense)
parts.explanation: They have sold their house.

parts.statement: I know him. (Change into passive voice)
parts.explanation: He is known to me.

parts.statement: If you do not work hard, you will fail. (Rewrite the sentence using 'Unless')
parts.explanation: Unless you work hard, you will fail.

parts.statement: She shuts the door. (Change into interrogative)
parts.explanation: Does she shut the door?

options.text: On the top of a hill
At the bottom of a hill

questions.text: Read the following extract and answer the questions given below:
questions.passage: He looked at the card, then at M. Loisel. He had never seen her look so cross. 'What is the matter?' he stammered. She replied, 'I am vexed not to have a jewel—nothing to put on. I shall look poor. I would almost rather not go to the party.' He replied, 'You can wear natural flowers. They are very chic at this season.' She was not convinced. 'There is nothing more humiliating than to look poor among a lot of rich women,' she said. Then suddenly her husband cried out, 'How stupid we are! Why don't you go and ask your friend Madame Forestier to lend you some jewels?'

parts.statement: From which lesson has this extract been taken?
parts.explanation: The characters M. Loisel and the mention of asking a friend for jewels ('Madame Forestier' is implied) relate to the story 'The Necklace'.

parts.statement: What does 'vexed' mean?
parts.explanation: 'Vexed' means annoyed, frustrated, or worried.

parts.statement: What was Loisel's wife afraid of?
parts.explanation: She says, 'There is nothing more humiliating than to look poor among a lot of rich women.'

questions.text: Read the following extract and answer the questions given below:
questions.passage:
Some say the world will end in fire
Some say in ice.
From what I’ve tasted of desire
I hold with those who favor fire.
But if it had to perish twice,
I think I know enough of hate
To say that for destruction ice
Is also great
And would suffice.

parts.statement: The poet of this poem is:
parts.explanation: The poem 'Fire and Ice' is written by Robert Frost.

parts.statement: What does 'ice' stand for?
parts.explanation: In the poem, 'ice' is symbolic of coldness, indifference, and hatred.

parts.statement: What is the meaning of 'perish'?
parts.explanation: 'Perish' means to die or be utterly destroyed.

questions.text: Answer the following questions in 30 words: (any six)

parts.statement: Who or what did Lencho have faith in? What did he do?
parts.explanation: Lencho had deep faith in God. He wrote a letter to God, asking for a hundred pesos to sow his crop again and live until the new harvest.

parts.statement: What did Nelson Mandela think about the oppressor?
parts.explanation: Mandela believed the oppressor is a victim of hatred and prejudice, just as the oppressed is a victim of cruelty. Both are robbed of their humanity.

parts.statement: Why does Anne want to keep a diary?
parts.explanation: Anne wants to keep a diary because she feels lonely and believes that paper has more patience than people. She lacked a true friend with whom she could share her deepest thoughts.

parts.statement: Where was the baker's furnace fired?
parts.explanation: The baker's furnace (or oven) was generally fired once a day, and the fire in it was never completely extinguished, ensuring it was ready for the next batch of baking.

parts.statement: What is the Chinese legend about tea? How is it different from the Indian legend?
parts.explanation: The Chinese legend says Emperor Shen Nung accidentally discovered tea when a leaf of a twig burning under his boiling water fell in. The Indian legend attributes its discovery to Bodhidharma, who cut off his eyelids, from which ten tea plants grew.

parts.statement: How was the flying of the Dakota plane unpredictable? How?
parts.explanation: The flying was unpredictable because the pilot suddenly flew into a huge black storm cloud, which was unexpected. Inside the cloud, the compass and other instruments stopped working, making the flight dangerously uncertain.

parts.statement: Who won the drawing contest? What had the winner drawn?
parts.explanation: Wanda Petronski won the girls' drawing contest. She had drawn a hundred beautiful sketches of dresses.

parts.statement: What does a 'jackfruit-like appearance' mean?
parts.explanation: It refers to a rough, bumpy, and ugly physical appearance, drawing a comparison to the bumpy, irregular surface of a jackfruit.

questions.text: Answer the following questions in 30 words: (any two)

parts.statement: What is a 'dust of snow'? What does the poet say has changed his mood? How has the poet's mood changed?
parts.explanation: A 'dust of snow' is fine, light particles of snow. The simple action of the crow shaking the snow from the hemlock tree changed his mood. His mood changed from despair/sadness to one of quiet joy and feeling saved for the rest of the day.

parts.statement: Why does the poet say, "I would not intrude on him"? Why doesn't he offer him money to buy another ball?
parts.explanation: The poet says he would not intrude to avoid interfering with the boy's personal learning experience. He doesn't offer money because the boy must learn to cope with loss and responsibility by himself; money won't replace the lost memory or lesson.

parts.statement: Is Amanda an orphan? Why does she say so?
parts.explanation: Amanda is not a real orphan. She wishes to be one because she constantly faces nagging from her mother, and she desires the complete freedom, solitude, and peace that she associates with an orphan's life.

questions.instruction: Answer the following questions (30 words): (any two)

parts.statement: Why does Mrs. Pumphrey think the dog's recovery is "a triumph of surgery"?
parts.explanation: Mrs. Pumphrey calls the recovery a 'triumph of surgery' because she believed Tricki's serious illness required complex medical treatment. The quick and complete recovery seemed miraculous to her, even though the cure was merely a controlled diet and exercise, not an operation.

parts.statement: What does he say about the different reactions of people when they are robbed?
parts.explanation: Hari Singh, the thief, observed that a greedy man shows fear when robbed, a rich man shows anger, and a poor man shows acceptance or resignation. This shows his deep, albeit criminal, insight into human nature.

parts.statement: Why does Mrs. Hall find the scientist eccentric?
parts.explanation: Mrs. Hall finds Griffin eccentric because of his strange appearance (bandages, large hat, dark glasses), his anti-social, irritable behaviour, and his consistent refusal to talk to her. His constant desire for solitude also contributes to her view of him as strange.

questions.instruction: Answer the following questions (75 words): (any two)

parts.statement: How did Mandela’s 'hunger for freedom' change his life?
parts.explanation: Mandela's 'hunger for freedom' transformed him from a fearful young man into a bold one. It compelled a law-abiding attorney to become a criminal, changed a family-loving husband into a man without a home, and ultimately drove him to sacrifice his personal comfort for the struggle for the freedom of his people, becoming one of the world's greatest statesmen.

parts.statement: Why does Maddie stand by and not do anything? How is she different from Peggy? Why?
parts.explanation: Maddie stands by and does nothing because she is poor herself and fears that if she speaks up against Peggy's teasing of Wanda, she will become the next target. Maddie is different from Peggy because Peggy teases Wanda out of thoughtlessness, while Maddie is acutely sensitive to Wanda's pain and feels guilty, though her fear keeps her silent.

parts.statement: How do you usually understand the idea of 'selfishness'? Do you agree with Kisa Gotami that she was being 'selfish in her grief'?
parts.explanation: Selfishness is usually understood as prioritizing one's own needs over the needs of others. Yes, we agree with Kisa Gotami's realization because, in her grief, she was so focused on her personal sorrow (bringing her son back) that she ignored the universal truth of death and the suffering of everyone else, making her pursuit a 'selfish' one in a spiritual context.

questions.instruction: Answer any one of the following questions:

parts.statement: Do you know the story of Rapunzel? Why does she (Amanda) want to be Rapunzel?
parts.explanation: Rapunzel is a fairy tale character with long hair, locked in a tower by a witch, with no stairs, only her hair to climb. Amanda wants to be Rapunzel because she desires a life of solitude, silence, and freedom high up in the tower, away from the constant nagging and controlling behaviour of her mother, which she finds oppressive.

parts.statement: What does the young boy say to Anne Gregory?
parts.explanation: The young man in the poem tells Anne Gregory that no man could truly love her for herself alone, but only for her beautiful physical features, such as her yellow hair. He implies that superficial beauty is what men are attracted to, suggesting only God can love a person purely for their soul, not their external appearance.

questions.instruction: Answer any one of the following questions:

parts.statement: What was the cause of Matilda’s ruin? How could she have avoided it?
parts.explanation: Matilda's ruin was caused by her excessive pride, materialism, and vanity—her desire to appear wealthy by wearing borrowed jewellery. She could have avoided it by being honest: either by simply not borrowing the item, or by telling her friend, Madame Forestier, immediately that she had lost the necklace, instead of replacing it with an expensive, genuine one.

parts.statement: Why does the marriage not take place?
parts.explanation: The question refers to the play 'The Proposal'. The marriage *does* eventually take place, but not peacefully. If the question implies 'Why is the wedding not happening easily?', the reason is the constant, petty, and ridiculous arguments between Lomov and Natalya over minor issues like Oxen Meadows and the superiority of their dogs. Their pride and temperamental natures prevent a smooth agreement.
